n64.name: Nintendo 64
n64.retroarch:
video_aspect_ratio = 1.142857143
input_player1_l2 = a
input_player1_l_x_plus = right
input_player1_l_x_minus = left
input_player1_l_y_plus = down
input_player1_l_y_minus = up
input_player1_left = S
input_player1_right = D
input_player1_up = E
input_player1_down = C
input_player1_r_x_plus = l
input_player1_r_x_minus = j
input_player1_r_y_plus = k
input_player1_r_y_minus = i

retroarch:
video_shader_enable = true
input_shader_next = rightbracket
input_shader_prev = leftbracket
video_shader_dir = "/shaders"
screenshot_directory ="/screenshots"
input_screenshot = t
video_gpu_screenshot = false
input_exit_emulator = end
input_save_state = num1
input_load_state = num4
input_state_slot_increase = num3
input_state_slot_decrease = num2
input_audio_mute = m
input_reset = h
input_toggle_fullscreen = f12
input_hold_fast_forward = space
input_player1_select = shift
video_vsync = false
audio_latency = 96
video_font_size = 32
video_force_aspect = true
video_smooth = false
rewind_enable = true
input_frame_advance = nul

scale2x.title: Scale2x
scale2x.notes: Eric's Pixel Expansion (EPX) is an algorithm developed by Eric Johnston at LucasArts around 1992 when porting the SCUMM engine games from the IBM PC (which ran at 320×200×256 colors) to the early color Macintosh computers, which ran at more or less double that resolution. Later implementations of this same algorithm (as AdvMAME2× and Scale2×) have a slightly more efficient but functionally identical implementation.

scale2xplus.title: Scale2x-PLUS
scale2xplus.notes: An improved version of the Scale2X algorithm modified to work better with 24-bit RGB images.

scale2xSFX.title: Scale2xSFX
scale2xSFX.notes: An improved version of the Scale2X algorithm

scale3x.title: Scale3x
scale3x.notes: The AdvMAME3×/Scale3× algorithm can be thought of as a generalization of Scale2x to the 3× case. The corner pixels are calculated identically to Scale2x.

scale3xSFX.title: Scale3xSFX
scale3xSFX.notes: An improved version of the Scale3X algorithm
